results.description:
Running is a good workout. Running up a hill is an awesome workout. Be awesome!


Every week is an adventure in hill work. Every week is different. Some workouts include...


30 minute continuous run. Sprint up the 0.4 mile incline, touch the graffiti wall at the top, turn around and jog back to the bottom and then repeat.

http://vimeo.com/81450322

Timed interval sprints. 45 seconds as hard as you can up. 1 minute and 45 seconds recovery jog back to the start. You will be winded!

http://vimeo.com/81966561

Obstacle course training. Workout stations with short sprints between them. Sprint to the first, do a bunch of situps. Sprint to the next, do some lunges. Sprint a bit further and do some squats. Sprint to the top and do some pushups. Jog back to the start and repeat.

This event is officially hosted by The Rise, NYC. They host morning workouts every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday mornings. See them on meetup here:


http://www.meetup.com/The-Rise-NYC/


NOTE: there is NO secure place to store bags, valuables, etc. Please use caution and do not bring anything you cannot afford to lose. If you do leave your belongings at the bottom of the bridge (where we start running) be aware that there is a lot of foot traffic and it would not be surprising if something "walked away."
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the bottom of the Manhattan side of the Williamsburg Bridge.
results.name: Hill Running Challenge with The Rise

group.name: NYC Informal Running Club: Home of TMIRCE:NYC

results.description:
Other than strict RSVP rules (if you say you're coming and you don't show, you're out of the group), this is a chill game, open to anyone who <a>signs up</a>.

Here's what separates this group from many others:

• Chill, positive attitudes. (People without forgiving personalities don't last long in this group, let alone in a given game.)

• Good quality equipment: $145 match balls; solid small goals - not pop-ups!

• Freshly laundered, adult-size, pillowy soft pinnies.

• We won't ever over-crowd a game. The size of pitch we use is best suited for 7v7. We're happy to make the pitch smaller if numbers are low. But we won't make it bigger or allow more than 7 players per team. 


• The small fee we ask of each player (at least $3 per session) supports a non-profit that we created and run: a high school soccer league for under-funded schools that don't have sufficient resources for after-school programming. 

See nyisl.com or the below video for more info. about our <a>program</a> for under-served public school students.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WzbNWu-N-ig

We use your game-fee to help pay for our high school players' new soccer boots, socks, shin guards and much more (e.g., the league website, goals, and other equipment). 

We're particularly fond of in-kind donations: soccer boots, socks, shins, shorts, etc. 

If you have any of these, please bring them to your game and we'll be more than happy to waive your game fee!
results.name: Sign-Up Soccer for Social Change

results.description:
LEADER:  Chris Connolly ([masked] (pref.)[masked])

RATING: B 7 B

Celebrate 2016 with a winter walk in a place full of wonders. Meet 10 AM at Reeves Meadow Parking Area. Come prepared for winter weather conditions (i.e., foot traction, no cotton, layers, water and food -- see below for additional guidelines).  TC Harriman-Bear Mountain Trails South map 118.

* * * * * *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities. Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance.

Pace Ratings:
A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster
B = Moderate - about 2 mph
C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less

Distance:Noted in miles

Terrain Ratings:
A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents,
possible rock scrambling
B = Moderate climbs and descents
C = Generally flat with little elevation change

For example, a hike rated “B-7-A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling.

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike.

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

Risks: As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

Footwear and Clothing: Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes. Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

Drink and Food: Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

Other responsibilities: Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them. Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian. No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21. The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike. Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

Maps: The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

Abbreviations: NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

Expense Sharing: When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

Dog-Friendly Hikes: Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly." If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event). If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.name: New Years Day Ride at Round Valley

results.description:
This is the New Year's Day crazy ride and an East Village tradition for the last 15 or 20 years. No one seems to be able to remember. Gather at East 7th Street and Avenue A around 10am and when the founder of the ride (an old tattoo artist named Skull) shows up around 12, everyone hops on their bikes and tries to loop Manhattan as fast as they can. Rain, snow, sleet, slush...it doesn't matter. There is no great deal of organization (or none that lasts past the first few blocks), it just is what it is... My experience with this ride is that it is fast and dangerous and not for the faint of heart, and the best part has always been hanging out for a few hours in the freezing cold on Avenue A before it all kicks off.

Some video from 2014 to give you an idea...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bPO_5feBwmM
results.name: The Isle of Man(hattan) Ride

results.description:
Mitsuwa mochi new years festival ＜Mochitsuki (Mochi Pounding)＞
Mochitsuki is a one of the traditional activities of the New Year celebration in Japan.
The cooked rice is pounded by two people with a wooden hammer (KINE) in a traditional large wooden bowl (USU).
One person pounds the mochi with a KINE and the other one wets and repositions the mochi between each stroke.
They must keep a steady rhythm.
Enjoy powerful performance and fresh and fluffy taste of mochi after that!!

＜Shishimai Lion Dance & Taiko Performance＞
Shishimai is the Japanese national art performance that started from the Edo period.
It represents banishing of the devil and celebrating livelihood.
Please enjoy this vigorous performance with Japanese Taiko.

ShiShimai Lion Dance & Taiko 10:00am
Mochi Pounding 12:00pm

Also, Special Lucky Bags are on sale from 1/1(Thu) while supplies last.
Limited quantity. Do not miss it!!
results.name: Mochitsuki (Mochi Pounding)

Let's celebrate the New Year together on our first run of 2016! We can swap stories from New Year's Eve and share our running resolutions...or just commiserate over our hangovers!

We'll meet just inside the park entrance at 52nd St. and 39th Dr. at 11:00am for a casual 5-mile loop. You can run at your own pace and know that we'll never leave you behind. For your safety, please be sure you can comfortably complete the full distance.

results.description:
Ready to take on the New Year?

Join us for a brisk hike along Fort Tilden beach! Meet American Littoral Society Chapter naturalists Don Riepe and Mickey Maxwell Cohen at Fort Tilden in the Rockaway Artist Alliance Building for a brisk hike along the beach and dunes. As per our 31-year tradition, at 12 noon, we will attempt to signal across the harbor to our colleagues at American Littoral Society headquarters in Sandy Hook, NJ. Enjoy goodies including coffee, cake and champagne afterwards at the Rockaway Artists Alliance. Please contribute to our celebration by bringing some snacks to share!

DIRECTIONS TO FORT TILDEN: Subway & bus: Take the #2 or #5 train to Flatbush Ave. / Brooklyn College and then the Q-35 bus past Floyd Bennett Field and just over the Gil Hodges memorial Bridge. Ask driver to let you off at Ft. Tilden.

results.description:
About 8 miles in about 4 hours.

We will walk north on Fort Washington Avenue past Bennett Park, site of Fort Washington in the Revolutionary War, then continue north into Fort Tryon Park, past the Cloisters, into Inwood Hill Park, then walk east to 10th Avenue and south to Dyckman Street. This part of the walk will be 4 to 5 miles; from here you can drop out of the walk and get either the 1 train at Nagle Avenue or the A train at Broadway.

Next, we will walk south along the Harlem River Drive to 155th Street, which will be about 3 miles. 

The D train is available on Frederick Douglass Boulevard, in front of the Polo Grounds Houses, and the C train is available at 155th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. If you walk a few more blocks across town, you can get the 1 train at 157th Street and Broadway.

Explore the north end of Manhattan along the Great Saunter Path.  Visit Inwood Hill and Highbridge Parks.  Welcome the New Year’s by walking the shores, parks of upper Manhattan.  See hills, great wild parks, historical sites, shoreline on the Harlem River.


MEET: 12 noon at the George Washington Bridge Bus Station Temporary Waiting Room at 179th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

LEADER: Cy & friends; Email: [masked].

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for paid annual Shorewalkers members, $3 for non-members, visit www.shorewalkers.org to join. If you are not a paid Shorewalkers member, please pay the hike leader at the beginning of the hike.
results.name: Happy New Year's Day Hike

results.description:
JOC POLAR BEAR SWIM "at Coney Island" IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN! Jan 1st (Friday)

Hey gang,
The First event of the New Year: "FREEZE yourself from the past" (LITERALLY) and plunge into the Atlantic Ocean as we swim with the Polar Bears Club!!

Ha! If the last couple of days are any indication, we may even enjoy beautiful beach weather! Always wanted to try the Polar Bear Swim, but never had it in you??? NOW IS YOUR CHANCE!

The annual polar bear swim is a world famous event organized by Brooklyn's Coney Island Polar Bear Club (http://www.polarbearclub.org). Each New Years Day, they attract hundreds of swimmers and spectators for one of the biggest winter beach parties imaginable. If you love challenges (or you just want a good laugh), come meet us there! 
We should get anywhere from 20-30 psycho JOC'ers for this event. With a little luck, we'll be on TV! 

Organizer(s):
Avi Golden ([masked])

Moshe Wolcowitz ([masked])


SO WHAT EXACTLY GOES ON?
We will be meeting on Sunday, January 1, 2016 at 12pm at the Coney Island beach in Brooklyn in front of the Wonder Wheel Ferris wheel on the boardwalk. The polar bear plunge officially begins at 12:45PM, but we are meeting earlier so that we can go as a group to the water. 

SO HOW DO I GET THERE?
It's easy. Just take the subway to the Coney Island Stillwell Ave stop (D, F, N, or Q subway line), and when you leave the subway walk towards the beach (checkout driving and subway direction by www.maps.google.com) if you plan on driving to the following nearby address: Nathans Famous restaurant, 1310 Surf Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11224). At the intersections of Surf & Stillwell Ave, you will follow Stillwell Ave till then end and you will see the boardwalk, and as you walk along it, you'll see the wheel. It's a short walk so don't worry.

Feel free to use this wall as a forum for ride share. However, keep in mind that given the traffic in the area, arriving by subway is by far the preferred method of travel. 


WHAT SHOULD I BRING?
If you would like to swim, you'll need to bring lots of warm clothing, a towel, a hat, water shoes, and waterproof bags to store your wet gear. Please note: The sand is going to be cold so be sure to bring water shoes or your feet will freeze.

WHERE CAN I CHANGE?
There are changing rooms and restrooms at the beach.

WHAT'S THE COST? 
As we like to say, IT'S FREE TO FREEZE, BABY!

WHAT IF I DIE OF PNEUMONIA?
Our club has no money, so a lawsuit is pointless. Ok, seriously, it's a common myth that you can get sick from being cold. 
According to the American Lung Association, the flu and colds are only more common in the winter months because that is when the viruses spread across the country. Additionally, the event will have numerous life guards, and we will only be swimming for a few minutes (some people run into the water and run right out) so there is very little risk of hypothermia. In fact, the Coney Island Polar Bear Club cannot recall a single case of anyone ever developing hypothermia, and people have been taking the plunge at Coney Island for over a hundred years. 

YEAH, BABY!! SEE YA IN THE OCEAN!!!

 
Avi & Moshe!
results.how_to_find_us: closest address is 1310 Surf Ave on the Board Walk (near the Ferris wheel)
results.name: JOC Polar Bear Swim!!!

results.description:
RSVP's ARE CLOSED.


PLEASE READ THIS CAREFULLY BEFORE YOU RSVP. I TAKE THE RSVP PROCESS VERY SERIOUSLY AND I EXPECT THAT YOU SHOULD TOO. 

I have been doing this event on New Year’s Day for AMC for many years now.


Join me and AMC club members who do not have to RSVP, UNLESS you do not get last minute e-mails, on a fun fast paced four mile hiking tour of Central Park concentrating on the lower and middle part of the Park. We will move at a fast pace but we will stop a number of times to talk very briefly about what we see. Central Park is really a work of art and you will see why. You’ll learn about the history of the Park and its unique design features that many people are unaware of. You will be sure to see things you never saw before. Even if you have done this with me before-there is always something new. (especially since you may not have listened to anything I said the first time! ) I have led a shorter modified version of this event  for The Guides Association of NYC (GANYC).  This event will be even better.

We will meet BEFORE 1:00 P.M. Be ready to go. WE LEAVE ON TIME. NO FOOD STOPS.


MEETING DETAILS WILL BE SENT BY E-MAIL TO THOSE WHO RSVP ON THE EVENING OF DECEMBER 30, 2015. 

Please consider joining the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) http://www.amc-ny.org/ The Club offers many hikes, walks and events and is also active in conservation efforts and trail maintenance. Only a few of the many hikes and walks that are offered by AMC leaders are posted on Meetup. 

Since this event will be posted as a last minute hike to AMC club members, there is NO need for AMC Club members to RSVP for this-UNLESS –you don’t get last minute e-mails (Contact me –don’t post a comment-if you are a dues paying member a few days before the hike and I’ll tell you how to get these e-mails). 

Let’s leave 10 spaces for AMC Meetup members. (I am going to give preference to those who have attended hikes I have led in the past). Needless to say, please take the RSVP process seriously and be considerate. If you have been a NO SHOW on any of the previous AMC Meetup events that I have led or you abuse the RSVP process –see your Attendance History- please do not sign up for this event. Unfortunately your ship has sailed. 

I am going to ask that people not post any comments or questions prior to the event. You have more than enough information to do this once you get the meeting details. No offense, but I don’t need to know-and probably neither does anyone else- what you are doing that day if you can’t make it or what you think the weather will be. AFTER the event, post as many comments and photos as you like.

If the weather forecast is really bad, See Accuweather like I do, I will post a notice Friday morning by 10:00 A.M. WE GO IN COLD. 

If there is no notice, we go. We will finish by 5 P.M or so-probably in the  mid to lower part of the  Park.

results.description:
The traditions continues.......

Nothing clears your head better that a brisk hike on a clear day. The plan is to meet at State Line Lookout in the Palisades Park. If the weather does not want to cooperate..we will modify our plan. Moderate hike, flat, no hills about 4 miles loop or you can continue to make it longer. Located in northeastern Bergen County, New Jersey, the Park is part of the more than 100,000 acres of parklands and historic sites managed by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. (For information about the parklands and historic sites managed by the Commission in New York State, please click here.) The land in the NJ Section was the first that the Commission acquired after its creation in 1900 by the states of New York and New Jersey. The Commission had been formed to prevent the defacement of the famous Palisades of the Hudson by a handful of large stone quarries then in operation. [b]DOGS ARE ALLOWED[/b]

 Please Remember Vikki is the Trip Leader

Samadhi is the state of yoga, or pure consciousness. This state is our true nature and birthright. results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE AND THE TRANSPORTATION SECTION.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you for your cooperation.

Bring comfortable walking shoes and EXTRA LAYERS OF CLOTHING. WE WILL BE OUTSIDE MOST OF THE TIME, SO PLEASE DRESS PROPERLY FOR WINTER CONDITIONS.

The holiday lights will be up until at least January 6th.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will comment on some things (the background of some of the holiday lights displays) along the way, but you will have time to socialize with others. We will be stopping at points of interest.

This walk is about 4 1/2 miles and moderate paced. If you think that you will be lagging behind with 4 1/2 miles at a moderate pace, then this type of walk is not good for you.

Some of the route will be different from last year's walk. There are also a number of new holiday decorations including an inflatable Santa Claus that is 2 1/2 stories tall and a virtual Santa Claus in a second floor window.

I also have scheduled this walk on Thursday, December 24th and Saturday, January 2nd.

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John, the Event Host, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photograph.

Description: We'll first go past the "Blue Christmas house," where all the outdoor decorations are mostly in blue (not the traditional Christmas colors of red, green, and gold), which honors the divided household-a Christian husband and a Jewish wife. Inside, half of the house is decorated for Christmas; the other half is decorated for Hanukkah.

We'll also see an 800-pound robotic Santa Claus (he sometimes will have a conversation with you!), merry-go-rounds, Nativity scenes, stately trees bejeweled in colorful lights, inflatable figures, enormous wooden soldiers, dancing animals, candy canes, twinkling snowflakes, and much more.

One interesting house has holiday greetings illuminated in three languages: English, Italian, and Greek. On the side of the house, a large snowflake design periodically lights up as a Star of David. This house is incredible!

How the Dyker Heights' holiday light tradition got started:

In the mid-1980s, Lucy Spata started the tradition of the Christmas Lights. Lucy said, "when I first moved into the neighborhood, it looked like a funeral parlor during the winter." Lucy's neighbors didn't initially welcome her "over-the-top" holiday lights display. In fact, Lucy said that when one of the neighbors complained about the lights and traffic the lights attracted she told them either to join her with holiday decorations or to move out of the neighborhood. However, when another neighbor started to put up the flamboyant holiday lights to match Lucy's lights, this neighborhood tradition really took off!

We'll be finishing between 6:45 PM and 7:00 PM near the "D" subway station at 71st Street and New Utrecht Avenue.


We'll encounter displays that are very bright (like blast or flood lighting), so bring sunglasses just in case!

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time: The meeting time is (before dinner) at 3:45 PM. Allow extra travelling time because the "R" subway train is a local train and makes a lot of stops.

Meeting Place: The meeting place is outside of the entrance to Century 21 Department Store, which is located at 472 Eighty-Sixth (86th) Street, Brooklyn, NY. The Century 21 Department Store actually has three entrances (next to one another) on 86th Street. We'll meet in front of the first entrance, which is the entrance for Women's Outerwear and Handbags Departments.

Before the walk, restrooms are located downstairs in Century 21 Department Store. The restrooms are located downstairs near the Men's Suits Department. After we start the walk, we'll have very limited opportunities for a restroom stop because we'll be walking in mostly residential neighborhoods.

Public Transportation: Take the southbound "R" subway train to 86th Street and 4th Avenue. After getting off the train, go to the token booth level and make a left turn upstairs. At street level, walk east (on the southern side of 86th Street) for about half of a block to the entrances of Century 21 Department Store.

Driving Directions: This is a one-way walk, so we will not be going back to the starting point. If you want to take your car, you can park your car somewhere near the "R" subway train at 86th Street and 4th Avenue. At the end of the walk, you will have to take the northbound "D" subway train at 71st Street to 36th Street and then take the connecting southbound "R" subway train back down to 86th Street and 4th Avenue.

Finishing Time: This one-way walk will finish between 6:45 PM and 7:00 PM.

Finishing Place: We'll be finishing near the "D" subway station at 71st Street and New Utrecht Avenue. (The "D" subway train is the only subway line that runs in Dyker Heights, and it cuts through only one corner of Dyker Heights at 71st Street.) At the end point, you could take the "D" subway train, and if you want, you can take the northbound "D" subway train to Atlantic Avenue, where you can then switch to another subway line.

Rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions or the forecast is for rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Friday morning. This walk will only happen in good weather conditions. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.
results.name: Bay Ridge and Dyker Heights Holiday Lights Walk (Jan 1)

PLEASE RSVP ON DHARMA DRINK MEETUP PAGE (www.dharmadrink.com - thank you!)

 

A great way to get Dharma connected in New York!

Meeting monthly at the Rubin during the summer - but special events will be announced like "Dharma Drink at the Beach or the Park" plus special group visits to see amazing teachers as the come to NYC over the summer!  Should be awesome!!!

 

For people interested in Buddhism or meditation or just leading a kinder life who are up for meeting like minded people.

Dharma Drink is now Self Service!

The table is always reserved in the same spot - just show up and see what happens  - just like if you were hanging out meeting other Buddhists randomly in Kathamandu or India. And don't take the RSVP too seriously - people are coming now who don't RSVP. The word is getting out....

Everyone is invited! Dharma Drink is all about building community amongst the Buddhist and like minded crowd in New York City. I was inspired to start Dharma Drink by hanging out with all of the great students of all of the different lamas in Kathmandu - Kagyu, Nyingma, Sakya, Gelug - totally Rimey (also Zen, Thai, Theravadan, yoga travelers, just about everyone!).  We all became great friends and learned from each other. We're there every Friday night - see you there.


Motivation:  To make the Rubin Museum Lounge on Friday night the Buddhist  hang-out spot in New York.

Who:  ALL ARE INVITED.  Feel free to spread the word.  The more, the merrier.

Time:  6-?pm
Date:  Every Friday - like clockwork
Place:  Rubin Museum Lounge, 17th Street and 7th Avenue
How to find us:  Look for a table with the small sign "Dharma Drink"                          + Lounge staff  will know where we are.

 

www.dharmadrink.com
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be at a high-top table with little sign that says Dharma Drink opposite the Ganesh statue - the lounge staff will know where we are in case you get totally lost.
results.name: Dharma Drink: the hangout for Buddhists and like minded people

results.description:
Free Usui Reiki Level 1 Distant Attunement

</a>The Padmacahaya International Institute for Inner studies is providing free of charge the Usui Reiki Level 1 attunement (via long distance) and the Open Heart Meditation for the public (via written form on the website for printing.)  Anyone with a willing and open heart can do this. You can follow the link above or read about it in our discussion board  The attunement is offered every 1st of the month at 6:30pm your local time and the duration lasts 15 minutes.  Open Heart Meditation can be practiced daily - either once, twice or as much needed throughout the day.  It is suggested to continue with the daily practice of the Open Heart Meditation and Self-Healing once a day for at least 21 days to notice changes.

A professionally created Open Heart Meditation with music in the background can also be purchased online in Itunes  <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/open-heart-meditation/id677392454?i=677392941">https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/open-heart-meditation/id677392454?i=677392941 or CD Baby - http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/irmansyaheffendi2

Full day classes in the United States and in some parts of the World will be posted in the discussion board.

If anyone in the NYC area is interested in classes, please let us know.  There are two paths to choose from - Open Heart Workshops and Reiki TUMMO Workshops.  Both are so beautiful and lead you deeper into the heart to live a more joyful, peaceful life.

With Gratitude,
the NYC/Lower CT group.

results.description:
Come watch Inside Out and join us for a discussion on the mystical aspects of this film from a Rosicrucian Perspective. 


Description:

Growing up can be a bumpy road, and it's no exception for Riley, who is uprooted from her Midwest life when her father starts a new job in San Francisco. Like all of us, Riley is guided by her emotions - Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust, and Sadness. The emotions live in Headquarters, the control center inside Riley's mind, where they help advise her through everyday life. As Riley and her emotions struggle to adjust to a new life in San Francisco, turmoil ensues in Headquarters. Although Joy, Riley's main and most important emotion, tries to keep things positive, the emotions conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house and school.

(Named Best Animated Film of 2015 by New York Film Critics Circle)

All are welcome!
results.name: Mystical Movie Night: Inside Out

results.description:
Magic The Gathering: FNM

Are you looking for a way to play while meeting new friends and winning cool foil prize cards? Then Friday Night Magic is exactly what you're looking for! Try it out at HobbyTown and discover why Friday night is the best night of the week!

Every Friday* HobbyTown hosts a Friday Night Magic draft.

*Note: In months with five Fridays, the 4th Friday will be Two-Headed Giant sealed instead of Draft.

For Booster Draft Format

You don't need to bring anything with you to play. Basic lands are provided. Sleeves are recommended, but not required.

Registration starts at 6:45 PM and the event starts at 7PM. The entry fee is $15. Two prize packs will be added to the prize pool for each participant.

The tournament structure will be swiss with three rounds. Matches will be best of three.

Promo cards will be awarded to the top two finishers in each draft pod. Any remaining promo cards will be awarded randomly to players not in the top 2.

Promos are given to the Top 2 finishers in each pod, then any remaining promos are given out randomly to other participants.

For all the store events and for more, please visit our Facebook page:

facebook.com/HobbyTownNanuet

Looking forward to seeing you at FNM!
results.name: Friday Night Magic - Draft

results.description:
Great Films

Weekend of Jan 1. 2, 3

Happy New Year to All my Cinemaphiles! 

Let's go to the movies!, 

January 1, 2016   at 7 pm

Dir. Hou Hsiao-hsien. 2015, 105 mins. DCP. With Qi Shu, Chen Chang, Satoshi Tsumabuki. Living in the countryside since she was abducted during her childhood, Yinniang has become an unrivaled martial arts master. She is sent to kill her cousin, a military leader and a noble during the declining years of the ninth century Tang Dynasty. Hou Hsiao-hsien’s first film in seven years is a breathtakingly beautiful work, its stately rhythms punctuated by eruptions of dazzling fight scenes.


. Hou Hsiao-hsien is mesmerizing.

Your good buddies Khalid A. Rahmaan (It's Sooo Up & Coming Comedy) and LeClerc Andre Darguin (Fox Tv's Laughs) love dumplings and standup comedy, so we've started up a free comedy show that brings these two great loves 2GETHA. Rejoice! It's almost time for the Chinatown Throwdown at the ***NEW Britpack Theater! You can expect a boat load of delicious pork dumplings from our favorite local spot for FREE, cheap drinks and great standup comedy from the very funny: 

Aparna Nancherla (Conan)

Saurin Choksi (Fuse TV)

Molly Austin (NY Comedy Festival)

Brian Parise (The Stand Comedy Club)

Jenn Welch (Totally Normal Standup Show)

and

Samuel Comroe (Conan)

7:00 PM Seating (Be on time. 1st come, 1st served and seats fill up FAST)

7:30 PM Showtime

- FREE Admission (Buy a drink or two, if ya wanna help us keep the lights on)

There will be beverages. Cash Only.

Come out to eat, drink and laugh with us at the beautiful new*** Brit Pack Theater. See ya there!

AGE 21+

***(VERY IMPORTANT NOTE: Go to 34 Pell Street, 2nd Floor. If you Google Brit Pack, you will get the old location on Lafayette street, which is now closed.)
results.name: Free Dumplings & Drink Giveaways @ the #ChinatownThrowdown Comedy Show

results.description:
A Hamburger Crawl?! Why hamburgers? Is this guy crazy?! Perhaps, but I really just think I'm hungry. I LOVE hamburgers and I know you do too. Hamburgers are the #1 comfort food in the United States so it's not just me. Let's get together and eat hamburgers. 

While this event is geared towards singles in the 21 to 49 age range, anyone of any age is welcome to attend. 

When you come to a Date Walking event, you will take a casual stroll with anywhere from 5 to 15 wo/men over the course of around an hour. It's a really fun and relaxed way to meet someone special or multiple possibilities face-to-face. You can check out some photos from previous Date Walks here. 

We will meet at Buffalo Wild Wings at 7 PM and wait 20 minutes for everyone to arrive. Please note that we are only meeting at Buffalo Wild Wings. We will not be eating hamburgers there. 

We will be crawling to 2 hamburger joints and they are very close so there will not be a lot of walking in sub-zero temps. The first place is Twist and Smash’d and the second spot isCheeburger Cheeburger. I chose these establishments based on location, the speed of food delivery and the ability to accommodate a large group of ravenous meat eaters. 

If you are a vegan/vegetarian or you do not want to eat hamburgers, that's ok. You can just come to meet people. By the way, if you can't or do not want to eat 2 hamburgers, you can split hamburgers with a buddy. 

After our crawl we can get drinks somewhere. 

Rain Date: If it rains this walk will be postponed. 

When you come to the event pay $10 and I will provide you with a ticket that’s good for 30-days. Hold onto the ticket and come to any/all Date Walking events for 30 days. Just show your ticket and you're good to go. 

Why am I paying you a fee for a place I can go to for free? See the answer here. 

If you have any questions prior to or on the day of the event, please do not hesitate to give me a call or text at [masked]

Thank you, 
Beau, your Date Walking Organizer 
  Call/Text:[masked] 
Email: [masked] 
Date Walking | Facebook | Twitter
results.name: Forest Hills Singles Hamburger Crawl

results.description:
Over and over and over. We are on auto pilot now, so we will have this, or another event, at a place to be determined, (TBI), every two weeks, with a pancake or some other panic event tossed in to keep everyone aggravated to the fullest.

As usual, if you RSVP 'yes' but can't make it, call me; your merry group organizer, Greg, at[masked] 1066.

And the standard 'It's ok to come late, or bring well behaved young ones' is in effect as well. 

Veggie Heaven is open till 11pm, and sometimes later(we loose track of time, someone keeps ordering scallion pancakes, and the staff is slow to tie up the evening's loose ends, so we are usually there for a good spell, I think 12AM is our record). Thus, lateness due to scheduling issues, etc, is no biggie. 

If we have a change of venue, for any given week, we will let you know in advance.

results.description:
Movie:TBD

We will hang out, eat snacks, watch movie and hang out some more. 


Please bring a snack or beverage to share with others. Feel free to bring dinner for yourself in case you haven't eaten dinner.

To get to Brian's apartment:

The best way is to take the 7 train to 90th street Station. Exiting  the train, walk to the left and then, make a right onto 89th street. You will walk straight down 89th street past four avenues until you reach Northern boulevard. 

As you keep walking on 89th street, you will pass a red Santander bank. My place is across the street from a small park on 89th street.

**Please note it is a 10 minute walk in total to my place.   
Please note I do have a cat named Chewy who looks forward to meeting you.

Press buzzer 23

Take elevator to 5th floor. Make a right through the grey fire door and walk to the end of the hall to apartment 510. 

There are other ways to get to my place but I think this is the simplest since you only take the 7 train and walk straight down 89th street to my apartment.

results.description:
Come join this wonderful on going FRIDAY EVENING co-ed (men and women) Yoga Class 7:15-8:15pm.  This is an adult yoga class for all ages and levels (if interested in children's yoga, please contact me).  Beginners are welcome and encouraged to join.  NO gym membership required.  Reiki is part of the entire class, however specifically given to each person during the quiet beginning of the class (meditation and centering) and at the end of the class during Savasana (the final pose). Each person receives Reiki during the entire class.  If you have a mat, you can bring it.  If you do not have a mat, I have some to share.  Please visit

www.CliftonYogaNJ.com

for more information or you can email through this meetup group or at [masked]. Text or call (email and text are fastest) directly (862) 621-9642.


Your first class is $10.  Future classes are sold in groups of 4 classes for $40 (still $10 per class).  NO gym membership required.  If you miss a class, you do NOT lose the class- it just stays in your account for future use :) but expires one year from purchase.  This is a wonderful class that builds upon your connection to your inner voice, connects you to your inner wisdom and divine consciousness.  You will build strength, flexibility and peace of mind... come join our group! :)

results.description:
REST / BALANCE / RESTORE
Winter is the Yin time of year; a time to go inward, slow down, and be mindful. In the first part of this workshop, I will teach a Yin yoga sequence focusing primarily on supporting the kidneys (the organs associated with winter) and the sister organ, the urinary bladder, which will help calm during this very busy time of year.

2- I will then lead the group through Divine Sleep Yoga Nidra, a guided meditation that systematically guides and relaxes you at every level of being including your physical, energetic, mental, emotional, and spiritual layers (koshas). Through the use of breath awareness, body scanning, healing music and nature imagery, Divine Sleep invites you to become aware of each layer of being without needing to change or fix anything. This is true meditation where there is nothing to do but ‘notice’ – supporting you in feeling empowered and whole just as you are.

With all the activity and busyness that surround the begging of winter, the holidays, and more, it’s easy to lose touch with our ‘inner guide’. This workshop will give you the time, space, and focus to quiet the active thinking mind so that you can re-connect with the wise part of your being. A wonderful gift to give yourself!
$30
results.name: Yoga Nidra - the yogic sleep with Maria Baez-Dominguez

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and TurnOn. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in NYC? We play 3 communication game (you can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you). Imagine meeting new people in an environment where people felt comfortable to be themselves. That's what we have created.

It's a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation.

You get the opportunity to examine yourself. Through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses.

What comes up might surprise you!

At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation. What class you can take and what we have to offer so you can have the life that you want.

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real. In an hour and some you may even forget for a moment you are in New York City.

OneTaste NYC is an organization teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without having to actually do the practice (or remove any clothing!).

It's a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good. This allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

Come early, doors close at 8:40p. COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions contact [masked] |[masked]

Can't make this one? visit us at www.turnonny.us
results.name: TurnON Brooklyn

venue.name: La Fama - Salsa Social

results.description:
The New Year is around the Corner and we are here to Welcome it. This Friday the 1st of January, La Fama is hosting its usual party in Times Square. Learn the basics, learn the moves, meet and greet, and enjoy the practice and dancing afterward. Let's do it!!

Class: The class is free with admission. It begins at 9:30pm and teaches you the basic steps, how to hold your partner, how to be on time with the music, and so on. You do not need to bring a dance partner since we rotate students so you get to practice with everyone else. But do bring your friends and have a blast. After the class, dance all night with all the people you met during the class. The instructor will usually be Silvio Neris.

Admission: $10. Note that this will be your only expense for the entire Friday night unless you buy a beverage. But you can also bring your own beverages if you want.

Time: The event starts at 9:30pm and ends at 2:30am or until the last dancers leave. Come at any time.

Location: Times Square 151 West 46th Street, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10036 (between 7av and 6av)

Dress code: Casual/comfortable. Bring shoes that don't slip out of your feet and do not have too much grip on the floor.

Salsa sample from instructor:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A2pJdAoKc4A
results.name: New Year's Salsa Social + Free Class @ La Fama

Friends,

Join us this Friday,  January 1 @ Monarch as we kickoff the New Year!

Monarch is conveniently located near Penn Station and other popular train stations. You are guaranteed to have a fun time at this venue. 

Get to meet a fun and diverse group of people.

This event is from 10:30pm- 3am.

Dress code is business casual.

Gents free before midnight. Ladies free before 1am (mention Rory's List to the door person upon arrival)

Don't forget to RSVP if you would like to join us.

You are always welcome to invite your family, friends and colleagues. 

We look forward in seeing you this Friday.

Contact us if you have further questions.

Cheers,

Rory

Join us this Friday,  January 1 @ Monarch as we kickoff the New Year!

Monarch is conveniently located near Penn Station and other popular train stations. You are guaranteed to have a fun time at this venue. 

Get to meet a fun and diverse group of people.

This event is from 10:30pm- 3am.

Dress code is business casual.

Gents free before midnight. Ladies free before 1am (mention Rory's List to the door person upon arrival)

Don't forget to RSVP if you would like to join us.

You are always welcome to invite your family, friends and colleagues. 

We look forward in seeing you this Friday.

Contact us if you have further questions.

Cheers,

Rory

results.description:
Great news! Plenty FREE PARKING on SUNDAY on street in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

We will return to our favor mountain - Hunter Mountain. It is closer, and has more and better trails. "As the Catskills' premier winter destination, Hunter Mountain celebrates renowned terrain, award-winning facilities and luxury mountainside accommodations together creating a smile on any snow lover's face! Discover Hunter's impressive array of mountainside amenities, including lodging at the Liftside Condominiums and the new four seasons, slopeside Katskill Mountain Club, plus a dozen unique mountain eateries speckled throughout the resort, two full service retail stores and plenty of programs for adults, children, and families."

*** Trip plan email via Eventbrite will be sent out 2 to 3 days before the event providing the details. ***

Date: January 2nd, 2016 Saturday. Please arrive 30 minutes earlier. 

Depart 5:45 AM from Queens: (Sheraton LaGuardia East Hotel) [masked]th Ave, Flushing, NY 11354 (Map)

Depart 6:30 AM from NYC: (Garden City Deli) Northwest corner of 43rd St & 9th Ave New York, NY 10036 (Map)

Return: Depart from Hunter at 4:30 PM and expect to arrive at NYC at 7:30 PM & Queens at 8:00 PM.

Cost: Includes all mountain lift ticket + round trip bus transportation - This is $17 to $20 off comparing to other bus tours. 
* Early birds $79 for first 27 spots
* Regular $89 for last 27 spots.

Additional Cost:
* $30 to upgrade lift ticket to Beginner Package which include lower-mountain lift ticket, rental (skis or snowboard) & group lesson.
* $39 for Ski or Snowboard Rental Package. Ski Rental Package includes skis, boots, poles & helmet; Snowboard Rental Package includes snowboard, boots & helmet.

Maximum: 55

Transportation: Bus is included.

Buy Ticket Here: http://jan022016hunter.eventbrite.com You can also Chase Quickpay me at [masked] to avoid transaction fee. (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) When Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location. Your spot is NOT confirmed unless your payment is received 

Refund Policy: 

* Full refund minus $20 processing fee if cancelled 14 days in advance.
* 50% refund if cancelled 7 days in advance. 
* Afterward, no refund for cancellation or no show.
*100% refund if the event is cancelled.

What to Wear & Other Info: Click this link for more info.

Check out more at http://www.huntermtn.com/

Group Ski/Snowboard Video: http://youtu.be/CLV84xRXANQ

http://youtu.be/CLV84xRXANQ

Previous Ski/Snowboard Events & Pictures:

http://www.nyskiclub.com/photos/12866882/ 
http://www.nyskiclub.com/photos/13377132/ 
http://www.nyskiclub.com/photos/13919452/

CHECK OUT ALL 2015/2016 TRIPS IN 3 APPS:
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/nyskiclub/events
Meetup: https://www.nyskiclub.com/events
Eventbrite: https://nyskiclub.eventbrite.com

By RSVP'ing "Yes", you and your guest(s) are accepting the terms to the Waiver & Release of Liability set forth by NY Ski & Snowboard Club.

</a>

<a href="https://www.facebook.com/nyskiclub">

results.description:

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Join us at 8am for a run to Hoboken Pier A and back.
http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/121375029

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

9 am we run to Liberty State Park, a favorite place to run for most of us. Run on!

When people hear about meditation, they almost always say that they have either never tried it or they were not able to do it. You may have expected that thoughts were supposed to go away, but when you closed your eyes, more thoughts than ever came up.

We invite you to come and experience how meditation can happen effortlessly with a little attention to our very own breath! The free session will include light yoga, breathing techniques and relaxing meditation and will be led by one of the volunteers of the Art of Living foundation.

results.description:
Details:

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.)  Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances.  We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation: 

We'll play rain or shine.  We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

results.name: Casual Saturday Morning Long Run

results.description:
If you sign up please be prepared for a looong day. We have an early start and we probably will be hiking out after sundown.Headlamps and proper gear is a must. No beginners please.


This hike has some strenuous climbs, and also offers fantastic views and long stretches of peaceful, breezy trails and woods roads. We will start at the Quarry Hill Road Parking area and hike up white past South Brace Mtn, Brace Mtn until we reach Alander Mt. We'll turn east on the Blue trail  and follow it down until we hit the Red trail and then visit  the NY/CT/MA tri-point monument and Mt. Frissel, CT's state high point. We then turn around and take white back down Quarry Hill parking area.

The peak of Brace is somewhat flattened out and treeless so it makes for relaxing views where you can find a soft spot to sprawl out on and take in the beauty of nature. You'll need the rest as the hike to Brace will get your blood pumping for sure. From Brace there is a great scene to the west. Brace hangs high over the farmland and neighborhoods dotting the valley below and affords great views of the mountain ranges in the distance.

*PLEASE READ*

Here is the weather forecast, you can make your own decision on whether you want to hike. :)

http://www.wunderground.com/weather-forecast/US/NY/Copake.html

NOTE: This is a challenging hike with about 3500+' vertical gain . It should take about 7+  hours, and we will be hiking at a steady pace. I will be taking some breaks for rest and photos though. :)  Please do your research and come prepared with the right gear and know how to navigate your way out!

PARKING AREAS: The parking area at Quarry Hill is quite small, please carpool as much as possible with big cars! 

DIRECTIONS:

Follow Route 22, 5.5 miles north of the traffic light in Millerton NY. Turn right onto Whitehouse Crossing Road. Follow Whitehouse crossing road to its end. Turn left on Boston Corners Road. After 0.2 miles turn right on Deer Run Road. Then left on Quarry Hill Road. You'll go up and then bend down to the right along Quarry Hill Road. As it flattens out a bit look to your left and you'll see a sign for South Taconic Trail and Taconic State Park. It's across the street from a house and just a barely visible dirt/grass parking area.

START: ﻿﻿﻿GPS Coordinates to Quarry Hill Parking Area

[masked],[masked]

Click Here for more detailed hike info

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

Уважаемые Бродяги!

После обильного Новогоднего стола не желаете ли прогулятся?

Перед прогулкой, конечно, Новогодний Чай!

 Ждем Вас :-)


Недалеко от NYC. Можно добраться на Metro North( Cold Spring station)

-----------

Total distance: 6-7 miles

You need:

 - Hiking Boots

 - Water

 ------------------

GPS:[masked],[masked]

Map: East Hudson Trails #102

Difficulty: intermediate

Driving Directions :

Take the Palisades Interstate Parkway to its northern terminus at the Bear Mountain Bridge. Cross the bridge and proceed north on N.Y. Route 9D for about 8.5 miles to its intersection with N.Y. Route 301 (Main Street) in the Village of Cold Spring. Continue ahead on Route 9D for another 0.7mile past the intersection with Route 301 to a parking area on the right side of the road, opposite the entrance to Little Stony Point. Train Take the Metro-North Hudson Line to the Cold Spring station, and walk north on Fair Street and Route 9D to the trailhead.

results.description:
Updated December 18th, 2015


WINTER (Dec-Feb)

As the city gets cold we play two times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd & West End) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd & West End)

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

Damien 


[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

[img src="">

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.
results.why: It's a great way to start your Saturday!

results.description:
About 7 miles and 5 to 6 hours.


We'll start at Columbus Circle, take a short walk into Central Park, then go to the American Folk Art Museum (suggested admission $5) at 2 Lincoln Square to view "Art Brut in America: The Incursion of Jean Dubuffet."

Here is a link to the exhibit: Art Brut exhibit

Here is a link to a review of the exhibit: Art Brut review

Next, we'll walk north though Central Park to the Whole Foods at 97th and Columbus for lunch, then north on Riverside Drive to the Roerich Museum at 107th Street (suggested admission $5) to view the collection of works by Russian artist Nicholas Roerich. We'll end the walk by visiting the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street (suggested admission $10).


We should be done at the Cathedral around 4:30. The 1 train is nearby at Broadway and 110th Street; the C train is available at Central Park West and 110th Street.

Meet: 11:00 a.m. inside the Time Warner Atrium at Columbus Circle, Take the 1, A, D or C train to 59th Street/Columbus Circle.


Leader: Tom Bergen[masked] [masked]

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for paid annual Shorewalkers members, $3 for non-members, visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.
results.name: Art Brut and Nicholas Roerich Exhibits

results.description:
This  discussion will be a sketch of the general principle concepts of Quantum Mechanics. We will discuss State Vectors and the Wave function, Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle, the Born Probability Postulate, Unitary Time Evolution, Commutation Relations, and  finally, the Time-Dependent Schroedinger Equation.

We begin at the beginning....why Quantum Mechanics is even necessary? Then progress to the conceptual foundations of this (oh-so-strange) theory which governs our microscopic universe.

Some math will be involved... none too heavy...an understanding of linear algebra will suffice

Here is some good background reading and videos....

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=JzhlfbWBuQ8

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_quantum_mechanics


And this one is relatively brief and very good, at about the level of this discussion....

http://www.colorado.edu/physics/phys3220/phys3220_fa08/notes/notes/Ch3_notes.pdf


Hope to see you there in the New Year!
results.name: The Principles of Quantum Mechanics

results.description:
Acoustic Guitar Lessons III for Beginners - JANUARY SESSIONS
Four 90-Minute Sessions Held on 4 consecutive Saturdays in January. [Jan 2, 9, 16, and 23]


The January Series continues where we have left off at the end of December and is open only to the participants who attended the 4-week Series held at 11a.m. on Saturdays  


WHAT YOU WILL LEARN:
In this workshop you will continue to expand your ability to READ NOTES, CHORDS and PLAY SONGS you know and love.  And what you learn can be applied to Rock, Blues, Folk, Country, Jazz, Classical or any other type of music the student is interested in playing.

Monthly Four-Week Cycles
In this workshop, a specific set of concepts will be covered over a period of 4-week.  Each monthly, 4-week period will be closed to people who did not attend the 1st session of the month.  This allow the group to continue to progress through the lesson material and avoid the need to review all that came before each time a new person joins the group. There will be three to four monthly, 4-week cycles before the first cycle is repeated


WHAT TO BRING:
• Bring your own guitar for these lessons
• Also bring a three-ring binder and a pencil

COST:  The cost of this session is $12.00, which must be paid when you RSVP.
results.name: Acoustic Guitar III for Beginners--January

results.description:
Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.

Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: Gotham Archery has reserved space for us from 11:00am to 1:00pm. Those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer at the regular range rate.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at Gotham Archery, you will have to take a safety & intro lesson class from the range staff and demonstrate safe shooting. No exceptions. Please arrive 15 minutes early; the class will start promptly at 11:00am.

Public Transportation: Gotham Archery is located at 480 Baltic St (Brooklyn, NY 11217) in Gowanus. It's a few blocks south-west of the Atlantic Av-Barclays Ctr train station. The 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, B, D, N, Q and R trains all stop there.

By car from LI:You can take the LIE, Northern State or Southern State to either Jackie Robinson or the BQE.  Set your GPS to 480 Baltic Street, NY, 11217.  The parking on Sat. AM isn't bad at all: you may have to circle the block once or twice.  The building is painted in a somber yellow ochre.

BUT: please consider car pooling or training it: the drive is awful; the train is lovely.  Most LI LIRR stations suspend parking fees on Sat and Sun.

You change at Jamaica and get in at the Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn-- walk south for about 7-8 minutes to Baltic -- go right.  Gotham is on the left.  The first time you walk here, you should have your GPS active.


 Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rate: $20 for two hours of shooting, $5 for equipment (plus sales tax). These discounts only apply during official club hours.

 Club Equipment: "Renting" club bows is free for members. We have four light- weight recurves and arrows, 3 righties, one lefty, plus arrows and armguards.  First come, first served, so please post as soon as you know you want to borrow club equipment.  If all of our club bows are not pledged to specific members, we will supply a member's guest with a bow on the guest's first shoot with the Group.

 See you on the shooting line!

Game description:

We'll play two simultaneous games of 7 on 7.
There will be 4 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!
Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.
No power shots allowed.
If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.
If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.
Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.
Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

A positive attitude, pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

results.description:
Join DM Noah Anderson as he runs the first D&D 5E Module over two parts!

The Sword Coast is siege. In an audacious bid for power, the Cult of the Dragon, along with its dragon allies and the Red Wizards of Thay, seeks to free Tiamat from her prison in the Nine Hells to bring her to the Forgotten Realms. The cult's forces are sweeping from town to town, laying waste to all who oppose them and gathering a hoard of riches for their dread queen. The threat is so dire, factions as disparate as the Harpers and the Zhentarim are banding together to battle the cult. Never before has the need for heroes been as desperate.

This campaign follows the module of the same name, and will be broken into two parts with six sessions each.
results.name: D&D 5E: Hoard of the Dragon Queen, Part 1

results.description:
First we'll visit two free exhibitions at the Lincoln Center library: The history of Alice in Wonderland performances, and the 100-year history of Symphony Space, the innovative Upper West Side culture center. Next we'll tour the nearby, newly relocated American Museum of Folk Art, featuring the work of so-called "primitive" artists. After the museum we'll have lunch at a cozy atrium, walk briefly in Central Park, then visit a cathedral-like temple, several Gilded-Age mansions, and a pair of art galleries.


PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING DETAILS SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED.

DISTANCE: About 3 miles.


PACE: Moderate, NOT SLOW. Please, if you want to saunter slowly this is not the right event for you!

LUNCH: Bring your own or buy food (light lunch, snacks, beverages) at the atrium.

COST: $2 for me, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee, plus whatever you pay for lunch if you don't bring your own.

ENDING TIME: Around 5 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

TRANSPORTATION: The closest subway stop is the  1 train at 66th St. Lincoln Center. For more details, consult mta.tripplanner.org, Google Transit (maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html) and/or a subway map, since those sites do not always list the ideal routes. Also check mta.info/weekender for weekend service changes.

WAITING LIST: Be patient. The list will shrink and often disappear due to cancellations, especially at the last minute. Don't worry about huge crowds: We've seldom had more than about 40 to 50 people actually show up.
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be wearing a red cap. Facing the Lincoln Center plaza from Broadway, the library is to the right of the opera house and slightly farther back.
results.name: Alice in Wonderland, folk art, lovely temple, mansions, galleries, & park!

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Ensemble class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome!

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."
results.name: Basic Improv for Public Speaking

results.description:
This months selection is an article on Delacroix and photography which can be read online at http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/issues/54/worth.php

The Invention of Clumsiness by Alexi Worth

If not necessarily correctness, what did Delacroix think photography could offer painting? The best glimpse of his thinking comes in two short essays written toward the end of his life, in which the painter sets out nuanced, ambivalent ideas about photography.Imagine yourself as an ambitious young Parisian artist in the 1850s. You belong to the first generation to have grown up with photography. At the same time, you revere Delacroix, and the imaginative, anti-academic idiom he represents. How would you reconcile the two? Judging by Delacroix’s own writings, the answer is clear: you would start from imperfect or faulty photographs.
results.how_to_find_us: 2 blocks south of Union Square on 5th Ave.
results.name: Delacroix: The Invention of Clumsiness by Alexi Worth

results.description:
Please join CAAF on our first demo of the year 2016!!!

Winter is still upon us, and as such, there are - unfathomably - STILL people out there who happily pay for the skins of fur-bearing mammals as "luxury" apparel for this frigid weather. That being so, Caring Activists Against Fur (CAAF), will be making its opposition to the horrific Chinese fur trade known to those unscrupulous cretins whose livelihood is the confinement, torture and extraordinarily brutal extermination of innocent beings - all in the name of fickle "luxury" and transient, superfluous "fashion."

Come and add your voice to a burgeoning group of energetic animal activists whose prime directive is to elevate public awareness about the plight of innumerable defenseless foxes, minks, raccoons, dogs and cats, and other mammal victims of the gruesome Chinese fur trade, who are violently and systematically removed from their natural habitats, corralled into inescapable death camps, crammed into tiny, filthy cages for months in ALL weather conditions, beaten, stomped on, anally electrocuted, gassed, bludgeoned to death, even SKINNED ALIVE so that affluent first-world consumers can gleefully, obliviously parade around, morbidly draped in the skins that are quite literally, ripped off these animals' backs as they helplessly writhe in overwhelming shock and agony 'til the final throes of death overtake them (minutes or even hours later!) These helpless animals are tortured and killed in the most horrifically cruel ways imaginable - all for vain, pretentious, human notions of "luxury apparel" and "fashion."

Jump into the ongoing campaign to STOP this insanity and work toward the total abolition of the global fur industry. Come out and HELP US make a vocal, public impact for the animals trapped and languishing in this insidious death trade, and to send a meaningful message to the heartless people who line their pockets with blood and entrails, who build their posh castles with the unspeakable screams of terror and suffering from countless innocent beings. For those unfamiliar with the realities of the horrible global fur trade, please take a few minutes to watch the following (Warning: graphic imagery!)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ueBWi8BL0PQ

Disgusting? Horrible? Unforgivable? Agreed! PLEASE come and help us to vocalize our extreme objection to this inexcusable, retrograde, medieval barbarism, to discourage/deter potential fur-shoppers from patronizing this retail dealer in death and torture, to enlighten the public to the grim realities behind their whimsical, self-deluding notions of fashion, and to encourage them to make more compassionate choices in shopping for winter apparel. In a world with so many great (and more economical) cruelty-free fabrics and styles, there really is ABSOLUTELY NO EXCUSE for this ongoing madness.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

WHAT: **CAAF Don't Buy Fur! demo @ Saks 5th Ave, NYC**

WHERE: Saks 5th Ave., 5th Ave. & 49th St. New York City, NY.
WHEN: Saturday, January 2nd, 2016.
TIME: 1:00 ~ 3:00pm

NYC SUBWAY INFO:

Closest Subways to Saks Fifth Avenue in New York City:
B/D/F/V at 47-50/Rockefeller Center stop and E/V/6 to 51th Street/Lexington Avenue stop.
You can also walk but it will take about 30 minutes. From Penn Station head towards W. 33rd St. via 8th, turn right on 42nd st., turn left on 5th ave.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

***

We will have plenty of signs, literature and relevant props to share with interested members of the general public. All YOU need to bring is yourself and your voice to speak up for the voiceless, who cannot articulate their own wish to freely live out their lives under the sun, to frolic and to bear young, to behave in accordance with their own natures with no interference from our species.

www.caafgroup.com
results.name: CAAF "Don't Buy Fur!" demo @ Saks 5th Avenue on 49th St in NYC
